ratings.comment: Dr. Gattis is a difficult professor to appreciate. Although he is very intelligent, it is clear that he lacks practice experience given his inability to demonstrate basic empathy in class. He goes on and on about micro aggressions but simultaneously makes arrogant and unkind micro aggressions to students. He doesnt make the world a better place.

Do not take this professor if you can avoid it. Dr. Gattis talks very fast and speaks low. He uses terminology from day one that  you probably are not used to comprehending in everyday conversation and by the time you process he has already moved on. His lectures and assignments are cloudy. I learned on my own with Youtube and my textbook.

Made me feel very stupid. Even going to his office hours he made me feel extremely dumb and unteachable. Cried on multiple occasions because of this class. Do not get me wrong I love a challenge, but that challenge needs to be back by a professor that loves to teach and encourages his students think outside the box and learn from diff perspectives.

Pray to god that you are completely current with the language for the course you'll be taking, because you're not going to be able to figure it out unless you've got a tutor or Youtube to hold your hand. One of the most cloudy lecturers I've ever taken who is a masterful PhD researcher, but absolutely terrible teacher. Take someone else if you can.

Easy class. Just make sure you go to it since attendance is a large portion of the grade. The exams are easy and the writing assignments are short. Both TA's are awesome!! Also, a lot of guest lecturers, but overall they are all interesting.

This class is easy, but the lectures are long and boring. The material is mostly focused on the history of social work, which I think could be interesting if Gattis tried to make it more interesting. He talks quickly and quietly, and it's difficult to take notes. My TA was wonderful, though. I learned way more in discussion than in lecture.

Lectures are very long and boring. There is too much on each slide to write down and will not give out slides before class. Expect a guest speaker once a week and know the information from them because it will be on the exam. The exams are very specific so if you don't study, you won't do very well. Assigns very long book readings as well.

Lectures are very long and power-point presentations aren very dense, don't expect to be able to take notes in class because he talks too fast. Computers are not allowed, so you better have good memory. Learned more in discussion than in class. Guest lecturers are redundant. Be prepared to hear a lot about homeless LGBT youth in Toronto.

A rather disappointing class that has a lot of potential. Professor Gattis is clearly knowledgeable but has a very boring teaching style. Very one sided political views are displayed which can get annoying. He is very friendly though. Expect guest speakers once a weak. 2 exams. 3 papers

Maurice is the best! The class requires two papers, 40 hours of volunteering in the community and 5 service learning journals that reflect on volunteer time. Every class in interesting and intriguing! Take this class! You will NOT regret it!
Great professor, really loves his field. Lectures are quite boring as he reads directly from the slides. Attendance mandatory. Very easy exams.

Gattis is very passionate about social work.  There are a lot of guest lectures.  The material is easy to understand, but the exams are a bit tricker than you would think.  He doesn't speak very loudly, and it seems like his microphone never works--try to sit towards the front or else you won't be able to hear him.

Prof. Gattis has lots of ongoing research which makes the lectures interesting. He's very helpful. Attendance is mandatory, book use high, many guest lectures, easy material, but watch out for the exams!
pretty good professor. very good teaching and accomodates many different types of learners. definitely take a class with him if possible!

Overall, the class is pretty easy. Class is mandatory and attendance is taken, however, material is easy to grasp. There are a lot of guest lecturers and TA's vary. Maurice is always willing and open to meeting and receptive of questions and comments via email and office hours! It was an overall good experience!
